references: To test the effectiveness of our framework, we conducted experiments on three real-world datasets: ML-1M1 11 11https://grouplens.org/datasets/movielens/1m/, ML100k2 22 22https://grouplens.org/datasets/movielens/100k/, and Book-Crossing (B-C)3 33 33http://www2.informatik.uni-freiburg.de/ cziegler/BX/. Both ML100k and ML1M are movie-rating datasets, and book-crossing is a book-rating dataset. We select three datasets with varying levels of sparsity for evaluating robustness to data sparsity- ML100k has the least sparsity, and Book-Crossing has the highest sparsity (for exact values, refer to table 1). All these datasets have explicit user preference in the form of ratings ranging from 0 − 5 0 5 0-5 0 - 5 for movie ratings and 0 − 5 0 5 0-5 0 - 5 0 − 5 0 0− −5 5 0 5 0 5 0 05 50-5 0-50 - 5 0 - 5 for movie ratings and 0 − 10 0 10 0-10 0 - 10 for book ratings dataset. We do not filter out users from ML1M and ML100k as each user has rated at least 0 − 10 0 10 0-10 0 - 10 0 − 10 0 0− −10 10 0 10 0 10 0 010 100-10 0-100 - 10 0 - 10 for book ratings dataset. We do not filter out users from ML1M and ML100k as each user has rated at least 20 20 20 20 movies in both these datasets. For consistency, we filter out users with less than 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 2020 2020 20 movies in both these datasets. For consistency, we filter out users with less than 20 20 20 20 ratings from the Book-Crossing dataset. While both movie-ratings datasets have clustering based on sensitive attributes like age and gender, this paper aims to boost performance on all weak users irrespective of the sensitive features. Thus, following the protocol adopted by  20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 2020 2020 20 ratings from the Book-Crossing dataset. While both movie-ratings datasets have clustering based on sensitive attributes like age and gender, this paper aims to boost performance on all weak users irrespective of the sensitive features. Thus, following the protocol adopted by [Li et al., 2021], we divided users based on their activity or the number of items rated. Any user who has rated items below a certain threshold [Li et al., 2021], we divided users based on their activity or the number of items rated. Any user who has rated items below a certain threshold t s subscript 𝑡 𝑠 t_{s} italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is termed an inactive user, and all those above this threshold are active users. We calculated the number of items rated on an average by all the users and used this average value as a threshold; this threshold can always vary and be set to different values per application. To test the effectiveness of our framework, we conducted experiments on three real-world datasets: ML-1M1 11 11https://grouplens.org/datasets/movielens/1m/, ML100k2 22 22https://grouplens.org/datasets/movielens/100k/, and Book-Crossing (B-C)3 33 33http://www2.informatik.uni-freiburg.de/ cziegler/BX/. Both ML100k and ML1M are movie-rating datasets, and book-crossing is a book-rating dataset. We select three datasets with varying levels of sparsity for evaluating robustness to data sparsity- ML100k has the least sparsity, and Book-Crossing has the highest sparsity (for exact values, refer to table 1). All these datasets have explicit user preference in the form of ratings ranging from 0 − 5 0 5 0-5 0 - 5 for movie ratings and 0 − 5 0 5 0-5 0 - 5 0 − 5 0 0− −5 5 0 5 0 5 0 05 50-5 0-50 - 5 0 - 5 for movie ratings and 0 − 10 0 10 0-10 0 - 10 for book ratings dataset. We do not filter out users from ML1M and ML100k as each user has rated at least 0 − 10 0 10 0-10 0 - 10 0 − 10 0 0− −10 10 0 10 0 10 0 010 100-10 0-100 - 10 0 - 10 for book ratings dataset. We do not filter out users from ML1M and ML100k as each user has rated at least 20 20 20 20 movies in both these datasets. For consistency, we filter out users with less than 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 2020 2020 20 movies in both these datasets. For consistency, we filter out users with less than 20 20 20 20 ratings from the Book-Crossing dataset. While both movie-ratings datasets have clustering based on sensitive attributes like age and gender, this paper aims to boost performance on all weak users irrespective of the sensitive features. Thus, following the protocol adopted by  20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 2020 2020 20 ratings from the Book-Crossing dataset. While both movie-ratings datasets have clustering based on sensitive attributes like age and gender, this paper aims to boost performance on all weak users irrespective of the sensitive features. Thus, following the protocol adopted by [Li et al., 2021], we divided users based on their activity or the number of items rated. Any user who has rated items below a certain threshold [Li et al., 2021], we divided users based on their activity or the number of items rated. Any user who has rated items below a certain threshold t s subscript 𝑡 𝑠 t_{s} italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is termed an inactive user, and all those above this threshold are active users. We calculated the number of items rated on an average by all the users and used this average value as a threshold; this threshold can always vary and be set to different values per application. Table  t s subscript 𝑡 𝑠 t_{s} italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT t s t ts s subscript 𝑡 𝑠 subscript 𝑡 𝑠 subscript subscript𝑡 𝑡𝑠 𝑠t_{s} t_{s}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is termed an inactive user, and all those above this threshold are active users. We calculated the number of items rated on an average by all the users and used this average value as a threshold; this threshold can always vary and be set to different values per application. Table 1 presents the statistics of all three datasets.

For the second phase, we design instructions for these weak users using the approach discussed inSection 3. Our results in Table 2 show that LLMs perform significantly well on these users. Using LLM and base RS models yields the best results for all three datasets. Our results show improvement in both AUC and NDCG@10 for weak users, thus demonstrating improved robustness to the sub-population of weak users. This further leads to an overall improved ranking quality. We also highlight that previous works like [Yue et al., 2023, Hou et al., 2024] show that close-source models perform much better than open-source. However, understanding the properties of users for which LLMs inherently perform well (like we provide a mechanism of finding weak users) and responsibly assigning tasks to large models improve performance using open-source as well as closed-source models. Our results show that Mixtral-8x-7b-instruct can perform almost equally well on weak users in all the datasets and base models. Furthermore, as observed for the ML100k dataset, this open-source model can outperform GPT-3.5-turbo when evaluated on AUC. It should be noted that AUC mainly evaluates the discriminatory ability of model to rank positive items over negative and NDCG focuses on the user’s satisfaction with the ranked list, considering both relevance and position. The reason for this can be associated with dataset sparsity. As shown in Table  [Yue et al., 2023, Hou et al., 2024] show that close-source models perform much better than open-source. However, understanding the properties of users for which LLMs inherently perform well (like we provide a mechanism of finding weak users) and responsibly assigning tasks to large models improve performance using open-source as well as closed-source models. Our results show that Mixtral-8x-7b-instruct can perform almost equally well on weak users in all the datasets and base models. Furthermore, as observed for the ML100k dataset, this open-source model can outperform GPT-3.5-turbo when evaluated on AUC. It should be noted that AUC mainly evaluates the discriminatory ability of model to rank positive items over negative and NDCG focuses on the user’s satisfaction with the ranked list, considering both relevance and position. The reason for this can be associated with dataset sparsity. As shown in Table 1, the sparsity of the ML100k dataset is lesser ( ≈ 93 % ) absent percent 93 (\approx 93\%) ( ≈ 93 % ) compared to the other two datasets. While Mixtral is a good choice when datasets are small and more dense, GPT-3.5-turbo performs well for extremely sparse datasets. Yet, it is important to note that in either case, the margin of the performance of both these LLMs is not significant, and thus, even open-source models can give a comparable performance. Nevertheless, usage of GPT model yields best NDCG@10 scores for all datasets. ( ≈ 93 % ) absent percent 93 (\approx 93\%) ( ≈ 93 % ) ( ≈ 93 % ) ( ( ≈ 93 % ≈ ≈ 93 % 93 93% %) ) absent percent 93 absent percent 93 absent absent percent 93 percent percent93 93(\approx 93\%) (\approx 93\%)( ≈ 93 % ) ( ≈ 93 % ) compared to the other two datasets. While Mixtral is a good choice when datasets are small and more dense, GPT-3.5-turbo performs well for extremely sparse datasets. Yet, it is important to note that in either case, the margin of the performance of both these LLMs is not significant, and thus, even open-source models can give a comparable performance. Nevertheless, usage of GPT model yields best NDCG@10 scores for all datasets.

references: For the second phase, we design instructions for these weak users using the approach discussed inSection 3. Our results in Table 2 show that LLMs perform significantly well on these users. Using LLM and base RS models yields the best results for all three datasets. Our results show improvement in both AUC and NDCG@10 for weak users, thus demonstrating improved robustness to the sub-population of weak users. This further leads to an overall improved ranking quality. We also highlight that previous works like [Yue et al., 2023, Hou et al., 2024] show that close-source models perform much better than open-source. However, understanding the properties of users for which LLMs inherently perform well (like we provide a mechanism of finding weak users) and responsibly assigning tasks to large models improve performance using open-source as well as closed-source models. Our results show that Mixtral-8x-7b-instruct can perform almost equally well on weak users in all the datasets and base models. Furthermore, as observed for the ML100k dataset, this open-source model can outperform GPT-3.5-turbo when evaluated on AUC. It should be noted that AUC mainly evaluates the discriminatory ability of model to rank positive items over negative and NDCG focuses on the user’s satisfaction with the ranked list, considering both relevance and position. The reason for this can be associated with dataset sparsity. As shown in Table  [Yue et al., 2023, Hou et al., 2024] show that close-source models perform much better than open-source. However, understanding the properties of users for which LLMs inherently perform well (like we provide a mechanism of finding weak users) and responsibly assigning tasks to large models improve performance using open-source as well as closed-source models. Our results show that Mixtral-8x-7b-instruct can perform almost equally well on weak users in all the datasets and base models. Furthermore, as observed for the ML100k dataset, this open-source model can outperform GPT-3.5-turbo when evaluated on AUC. It should be noted that AUC mainly evaluates the discriminatory ability of model to rank positive items over negative and NDCG focuses on the user’s satisfaction with the ranked list, considering both relevance and position. The reason for this can be associated with dataset sparsity. As shown in Table 1, the sparsity of the ML100k dataset is lesser ( ≈ 93 % ) absent percent 93 (\approx 93\%) ( ≈ 93 % ) compared to the other two datasets. While Mixtral is a good choice when datasets are small and more dense, GPT-3.5-turbo performs well for extremely sparse datasets. Yet, it is important to note that in either case, the margin of the performance of both these LLMs is not significant, and thus, even open-source models can give a comparable performance. Nevertheless, usage of GPT model yields best NDCG@10 scores for all datasets.
